text: For the sin of their mouth and the words of their lips let them even be taken in their pride: and for cursing and lying which they speak.
text_kjv: For the sin of their mouth and the words of their lips let them even be taken in their pride: and for cursing and lying which they speak.
text_niv: For the sins of their mouths,for the words of their lips,let them be caught in their pride.For the curses and lies they utter,
text_esv: For the sin of their mouths, the words of their lips, let them be trapped in their pride. For the cursing and lies that they utter,
text_nlt: Because of the sinful things they say,because of the evil that is on their lips,let them be captured by their pride,their curses, and their lies.
text_msg: Let all their mean-mouthed arrogancecatch up with them,Catch them out and bring them down—every muttered curse—every barefaced lie.
text_nasb: [On account of] the sin of their mouth [and] the words of their lips, Let them even be caught in their pride, And on account of curses and lies which they utter.
context: Psalm 59 is attributed to David, written when Saul sent men to watch his house in order to kill him. The historical backdrop is one of imminent danger and unjust persecution. Saul, driven by jealousy and paranoia, sees David as a threat to his throne and seeks to eliminate him. David, innocent of any wrongdoing, finds himself hunted and targeted by the king's forces. This psalm, therefore, becomes a desperate plea for deliverance and a condemnation of his enemies' wicked intentions. The cultural context of the time includes a strong emphasis on the power of words, both in terms of blessings and curses. Ancient Near Eastern societies believed that spoken words held inherent power to affect reality. Curses were seen as potent weapons, capable of bringing misfortune and destruction upon their target. Lying and deceit were also considered grave offenses, undermining social order and trust. Royal authority, particularly that of Saul, was generally respected, so David's predicament was exceedingly perilous. He had to navigate the delicate balance of remaining loyal to the divinely appointed king while also seeking protection from the king's unjust rage. This psalm reflects the moral and spiritual complexities of David's situation and his unwavering faith in God's justice.
meaning: Psalm 59:12 specifically addresses the consequences of the enemies' wicked speech. The verse highlights four aspects of their sinful communication: sin of their mouth, words of their lips, cursing, and lying. The phrase 'sin of their mouth and the words of their lips' speaks to the overall depravity expressed through their speech. It suggests that their words are not merely careless utterances but are rooted in a deeper moral failing. 'Let them even be taken in their pride' indicates that their arrogance and self-importance will be the very cause of their downfall. Pride, in biblical terms, is often seen as the root of sin, leading to rebellion against God and disregard for others. The verse connects their pride to their destructive speech, implying that their arrogant attitude fuels their malicious words. The inclusion of 'cursing and lying which they speak' emphasizes the active harm their words inflict. Cursing signifies the invocation of evil upon others, a direct assault on their well-being. Lying, on the other hand, represents a deliberate distortion of truth, aimed at deception and manipulation. Theologically, this verse underscores the concept of divine retribution. God is presented as a just judge who holds individuals accountable for their words and actions. The enemies' sinful speech is not merely a social offense but a transgression against God's moral order. The verse suggests that their punishment will be proportionate to their sin, specifically stemming from the very means they used to harm others – their words.
application: Psalm 59:12 has profound implications for our modern lives, particularly in an age dominated by digital communication. The verse serves as a potent reminder of the power of our words and the importance of using them responsibly. In a world where social media platforms allow for instant and widespread dissemination of information, the potential for harm through careless or malicious speech is amplified. We must be vigilant in guarding our tongues and ensuring that our words are truthful, edifying, and compassionate. Practically, this means being mindful of the content we post online, refraining from engaging in gossip or slander, and challenging hateful or divisive rhetoric. It also requires us to examine our motivations for speaking – are we seeking to build others up or tear them down? Are we driven by pride or humility? This verse challenges us to cultivate a culture of respectful and constructive communication, both online and offline. It calls us to be truth-tellers, even when it's difficult, and to avoid the temptation to use our words to manipulate or deceive others. Furthermore, the verse highlights the connection between pride and destructive speech. We must be aware of the subtle ways in which pride can manifest in our communication, such as boasting, arrogance, or a tendency to dismiss others' opinions. Cultivating humility and empathy can help us to avoid these pitfalls and to use our words in a way that reflects Christ's love and grace. Finally, the verse reminds us that our words have consequences, both for ourselves and for others. We will be held accountable for what we say, so we must strive to use our voices to speak truth, promote justice, and build up the body of Christ.
prayer: Heavenly Father, forgive me for the times I have used my words carelessly, thoughtlessly, or even maliciously. I confess that pride often creeps into my heart, leading me to speak in ways that are hurtful or untrue. Help me to be mindful of the power of my words and to use them to build up others, rather than tear them down. Fill me with your love and compassion, that my speech may be seasoned with grace and truth. Give me the courage to speak out against injustice and to defend those who are vulnerable. Purify my heart and my lips, that my words may always be pleasing in your sight. Help me to be a reflection of your love in all that I say. In Jesus' name, Amen.
